fields.description:
A simple use of reading a Parquet file using PyArrow crashes Python silently with no explanation. Sudden and strange. I've narrowed it down to reproduce it as follows:
{code:bash}
conda create -n pa36 python=3.6 pyarrow=0.17 -c conda-forge -y
{code}

Then, in python:
{code:python}
import pyarrow.parquet
tbl = pyarrow.parquet.read_table("some_file.snappy.parquet")
{code}
Result - It crashes. Maybe because of the Snappy encoding? FWIW, the files were generated by Spark on Azure Databricks, not pandas.
 

Here's the conda environment:
{code:bash}
(base) > conda env export{code}
{code:yaml}
 name: pa36
 channels: 
 - conda-forge
 - defaults
 dependencies: 
 - abseil-cpp=20200225.2=h33f27b4_0
 - arrow-cpp=0.17.1=py36h1234567_8_cpu
 - aws-sdk-cpp=1.7.164=vc14h867dc94_1
 - boost-cpp=1.72.0=h2ba7cf6_1
 - brotli=1.0.7=h33f27b4_1002
 - bzip2=1.0.8=hfa6e2cd_2
 - c-ares=1.15.0=h2fa13f4_1001
 - ca-certificates=2020.6.20=hecda079_0
 - certifi=2020.6.20=py36h9f0ad1d_0
 - curl=7.71.0=h4b64cdc_0
 - gflags=2.2.2=he025d50_1002
 - glog=0.4.0=h0174b99_3
 - grpc-cpp=1.30.0=hfae5148_0
 - intel-openmp=2020.0=166
 - krb5=1.17.1=hc04afaa_1
 - libblas=3.8.0=15_mkl
 - libcblas=3.8.0=15_mkl
 - libcurl=7.71.0=h4b64cdc_0
 - liblapack=3.8.0=15_mkl
 - libprotobuf=3.12.3=h7bd577a_0
 - libssh2=1.9.0=h3235a2c_2
 - lz4-c=1.9.2=h62dcd97_1
 - mkl=2020.0=166
 - numpy=1.18.5=py36h4d86e3b_0
 - openssl=1.1.1g=he774522_0
 - pandas=1.0.5=py36hcc50265_0
 - parquet-cpp=1.5.1=2
 - pip=20.1.1=py_1
 - pyarrow=0.17.1=py36h1234567_8_cpu
 - python=3.6.10=he025d50_1009_cpython
 - python-dateutil=2.8.1=py_0
 - python_abi=3.6=1_cp36m
 - pytz=2020.1=pyh9f0ad1d_0
 - re2=2020.06.01=h33f27b4_0
 - setuptools=47.3.1=py36h9f0ad1d_0
 - six=1.15.0=pyh9f0ad1d_0
 - snappy=1.1.8=ha925a31_2
 - thrift-cpp=0.13.0=h1907cbf_2
 - tk=8.6.10=hfa6e2cd_0
 - vc=14.1=h869be7e_1
 - vs2015_runtime=14.16.27012=h30e32a0_2
 - wheel=0.34.2=py_1
 - wincertstore=0.2=py36_1003
 - xz=5.2.5=h2fa13f4_0
 - zlib=1.2.11=h2fa13f4_1006
 - zstd=1.4.4=h9f78265_3
{code}

comments.body: This is probably a duplicate of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-7939
Thanks, you are correct, my bad.
Any information you can provide about the hardware (e.g. CPU make and model number) where it's crashing would be helpful

Weird... I can't reproduce it on my laptop at home, and I even setup a GitHub repo just to try reproducing it in GitHub Actions, but it seems to work fine there too. However, at my computer at work it was crashing - I'll update this issue tomorrow with its specs.

Link to GH Action: [https://github.com/yehoshuadimarsky/pyarrow-bug/runs/809395674?check_suite_focus=true#step:5:1]

Laptop CPU config (by running same [script|https://github.com/yehoshuadimarsky/pyarrow-bug/blob/master/output_config.py] from GH repo):
{code:java}
(base) PS C:\Users\JoshDimarsky\Documents\GitHub\pyarrow-bug> python .\output_config.py
The hardware config is:
{'compiler': 'MSC v.1915 64 bit (AMD64)',
 'machine': 'AMD64',
 'processor': 'Intel64 Family 6 Model 142 Stepping 10, GenuineIntel',
 'release': '10',
 'system': 'Windows',
 'version': '10.0.18362'}{code}
Your laptop (iX-7XXX) supports AVX2 so it should be fine.

Just tried it on my work PC, and it crashed - here are the CPU specs:
{code:bash}
(pa38) PS C:\Users\JoshDimarsky.AzureAD\Documents\GitHub\pyarrow-bug> python .\output_config.py
The hardware config is:
{'compiler': 'MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)',
 'machine': 'AMD64',
 'processor': 'Intel64 Family 6 Model 45 Stepping 7, GenuineIntel',
 'release': '10',
 'system': 'Windows',
 'version': '10.0.18362'}{code}
Confirmed it still crashes when using a Intel64 Family 6 Model 45 Stepping 7 GenuineIntel ~3601 Mhz CPU

Screenshot of my CPU from Windows settings if that helps:

!image-2020-06-26-10-17-04-121.png!

Yeah that processor doesn't support AVX2 / BMI2 instructions. 

This will be fixed by https://github.com/conda-forge/snappy-feedstock/pull/26 when it's merged, so once you update Snappy (after the package is updated) the problem should go away
Issue was related to BMI instructions issue with Snappy on 1.1.8 and only on Windows, was resolved in conda-forge build #3, see linked issue.
